newsitem.title: LUXEMBOURG: Court finds Belgium late to enact EU directives on gmos.
newsitem.headline: Court finds Belgium late to enact EU directives on gmos.

text.p: The European Court of Justice found on Thursday Belgium was late to enact directives on genetically modified organisms and the labelling of dangerous substances.
In two separate judgments, the court decided four cases submitted by the European Commission that demonstrated Belgium's lateness to enact local laws transposing EU directives.
The court did not accept Belgium's argument that national rules would be enacted soon, but stuck to their strict reading of time limits prescribed under the directives.
EXCERPTS FROM THE JUDGMENT
Commission of the European Communities
v
Kingdom of Belgium
application for a declaration that by failing to adopt within the prescribed period the laws, regulations and adminstrative provisions necessary to comply with:

Commission directives 91/41/EEC adapting to technical progrss for the fourteenth time Council directive 67/548/EEC on the approximation of laws, regulations and administrative provisions relating to the classification, packaging and labelling of dangerous substances;

Commission directive 93/21/EEC adapting to technical progress for the eighteenth time Council directive 67/548/EEC with the exception of the provisions of that directive applicable to mobile gas cylinders containing butane, propane or liquid petroleum gas and
Commission directive 93/99/EEC concerning the list of substances referred to in article 13(1) (fifth indent) of Council directiev 67/548/EEC
and/or by failing to communicate the measures for their implementatin, the Kingdom of Belgium has failed to fulfil its obligations under those directives
THE COURT hereby
1. Declares that, by failing to adopt within the prescribed period the laws, regulations and adminstrative provisions necessary to comply with:

Commission directives 91/41/EEC adapting to technical progrss for the fourteenth time Council directive 67/548/EEC on the approximation of laws, regulations and administrative provisions relating to the classification, packaging and labelling of dangerous substances;

Commission directive 93/21/EEC adapting to technical progress for the eighteenth time Council directive 67/548/EEC with the exception of the provisions of that directive applicable to mobile gas cylinders containing butane, propane or liquid petroleum gas and
Commission directive 93/99/EEC concerning the list of substances referred to in article 13(1) (fifth indent) of Council directive 67/548/EEC
and/or by failing to communicate the measures for their implementatin, the Kingdom of Belgium has failed to fulfil its obligations under those directives.
2. Orders the Kingdom of Belgium to pay the costs.
EXCERPTS FROM THE JUDGMENT
Commission of the European Communities
v
Kingdom of Belgium

application for a declaration that by failing to adopt within the prescribed period the laws, regulations and adminstrative provisions necessary to comply with Commission directive 94/15/EC adapting to technical progress for the first time Council directive 90/220/EEC on the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms, the Kingdom of Belgium has failed to fulfil its obligations under that directive
THE COURT hereby

1. Declares that, by failing to adopt within the prescribed period the laws, regulations and adminstrative provisions necessary to comply with Commission directive 94/15/EC adapting to technical progress for the first time Council directive 90/220/EEC on the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms, the Kingdom of Belgium has failed to fulfil its obligations under that directive
2. Orders the Kingdom of Belgium to pay the costs.
